conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is greater than or less than 75 meters, we need to analyze the area under the velocity-time (v-t) graph for that interval.
The area under the v-t graph represents the displacement (or distance fallen in this case).
The interval of interest is from 10 seconds to 15 seconds.
At t = 10 seconds, the velocity is approximately 20 m/s.
At t = 15 seconds, the velocity is approximately 10 m/s.
The graph between 10 and 15 seconds appears to be a straight line, indicating a linear decrease in velocity.

premise: The area under the graph from 10 to 15 seconds can be approximated as a trapezoid.
conclusion: The formula for the area of a trapezoid is: Area = 1/2 × (Base_1 + Base_2) × Height.

premise: Base_1 = 20 m/s, Base_2 = 10 m/s, and Height = 5 seconds.
conclusion: Substitute the values into the formula: Area = 1/2 × (20 + 10) × 5.

premise: The area under the graph from 10 to 15 seconds is exactly 75 meters.
conclusion: The distance fallen during the 10 to 15 seconds interval is exactly 75 meters. Therefore, it is neither greater than nor less than 75 meters.
